title: 114_hr2937
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Cuban Military Transparency Act" and includes a table of contents. The "Cuban Military Transparency Act" includes findings, a statement of policy, prohibitions on financial transactions with specific Cuban ministries, rewards for information on a past attack, coordination with INTERPOL, reports on Cuban ministries' roles in the economy and foreign relationships, confiscated property ownership, and termination. The "Cuban Military Transparency Act" includes findings. Congress makes findings regarding the normalization of relations with Cuba, including increasing resources to reach the Cuban people and supporting humanitarian projects, the Cuban private sector, and civil society. President Obama's statements emphasize promoting independence from Cuban authorities. Article 18 of the 1976 Constitution of Cuba states that the State controls foreign commerce. The largest company in Cuba, Grupo Gaesa, is controlled by the Cuban military and overseen by General Raul Castro's son-in-law. The United States House of Representatives voted to prohibit exports to the Cuban military and security services in 2015. The Cuban military operates resort facilities in properties confiscated from US citizens. In 2003, General Ruben Martinez Puente and two Cuban Air Force pilots were indicted for attacking US civilian planes. The 2003 US indictment against Cuban military officials is the only one against senior military officials from a state sponsor of terrorism for the murder of US nationals. In 2014, General Raul Castro admitted to giving the order to shoot down US civilian planes, resulting in the deaths of American citizens. Gerardo Hernandez, a Cuban spy exchanged by President Obama in 2014, was serving a life sentence for conspiracy in the deaths of three US citizens. The Cuban military's involvement in a 2013 trafficking incident with North Korea, violating UN sanctions and refusing to cooperate with investigators, was highlighted in a New York Times article. The incident included heavy weapons like MiG fighter jets and missiles, making it the largest intercepted weapons cache to or from North Korea. In February 2015, Colombian authorities intercepted a Chinese-flagged vessel carrying war materiel disguised as grain products destined for the Cuban military. The shipment included rockets, cannon shells, dynamite, and detonators. The Cuban military has provided military intelligence, weapons training, and security logistics to Venezuela, contributing to the subversion of democratic institutions and violent suppression of protests. The Cuba 2013 Human Rights Report highlights human rights abuses by the military during peaceful protests in Venezuela. SEC. 3. STATEMENT OF POLICY. The United States supports the people of Cuba in establishing basic freedoms, a democratic political system, and a government that does not oppress its people or persecute dissidents. Legal travel and trade with Cuba should not enrich the military or security forces run by the Castro family. Officials who commit crimes in Cuba should be brought to justice in the United States. The United States aims to bring Cuban officials involved in the 1996 attack on US civilian aircraft to justice and counter Cuba's efforts to promote repression in the Western Hemisphere, particularly in Venezuela. The US prohibits financial transactions with the Ministry of the Revolutionary Armed Forces or the Ministry of the Interior of Cuba. Beginning 30 days after the enactment of this Act, a US person is prohibited from engaging in financial transactions with the Ministry of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Cuba, the Ministry of the Interior of Cuba, related entities, or senior members of these ministries. The Act prohibits US persons from engaging in financial transactions with certain Cuban entities or individuals to avoid funding them, with exceptions for the sale of specific goods to Cuba. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 allows for specific financial transactions with Cuba, including medical device sales, remittances to family members, payments for Guantanamo Bay maintenance, democracy-building support, and routine financial transactions for the US Interests Section in Havana. The President will use authorities under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to implement restrictions on financial transactions with Cuba, prohibiting certain activities without issuing general licenses. Violators will face penalties. Violators of the restrictions on financial transactions with Cuba will be subject to penalties under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The term "United States person" includes citizens, permanent residents, and entities organized under U.S. laws. SEC. 5. Inclusion in Department of State rewards program for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals responsible for the February 24, 1996, attack on United States aircraft. Amends the State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956 to include rewards for the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in the attack on US aircraft by the Cuban military on February 24, 1996. The Attorney General, in coordination with the Secretary of State, will work with INTERPOL to locate and arrest US fugitives in Cuba, including former Cuban military members involved in the 1996 aircraft attack. They aim for extradition or legal action through international wanted notices. Additionally, a report will be made on the roles of the Cuban Ministry of the Revolutionary Armed Forces and the Ministry of the Interior in Cuba's economy and foreign relationships. The President must submit a report to Congress on the role of the Cuban Ministry of the Revolutionary Armed Forces and the Ministry of the Interior in Cuba's economy. The report will identify entities owned or controlled by these ministries and assess their business dealings with foreign countries. The report to Congress will include an assessment of the relationship between the Cuban Ministries of the Revolutionary Armed Forces and the Interior with foreign militaries, detailing joint training, exercises, financial dealings, and weapons transactions. The report will be submitted in unclassified form, with the possibility of a classified annex. SEC. 8. REPORT ON USE AND OWNERSHIP OF CONFISCATED PROPERTY.

The President must report to Congress on the confiscation and use of property by Cuban Ministries of the Revolutionary Armed Forces and the Interior. Definitions of "confiscated" and "confiscation" are as per the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act.

SEC. 9. TERMINATION.

This Act will end when the President determines a democratically elected government is in power in Cuba as per the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act.
